title: Ticket #7188: Bad warning about line endings
description:
Episode 1
When your job’s executable has Windows line endings, (rather than
holding with “exec format error” as in the past,) HTCondor now tells you to
submit some other way ... which doesn’t fix the line endings and results in
an even more confusing error message.

To be specific, the message from condor_submit.V6/submit.cpp line 1431 is "Executable file %s is a script with CRLF (DOS/Win) line endings", followed by "Run with -allow-crlf-script if this is really what you want", if that flag wasn't set. The former is fine, but the latter is almost never what anybody actually wants.

We should therefore not mention it. Instead, based on the CHTC's page, change the message to read "... line endings. This generally doesn't work, and you should probably run dos2unix <executable> -- or a similar tool -- before you resubmit."

Although dos2unix is not installed everywhere, just using tr involves a complicated construction to do an in-place replacement. (We could certainly print the whole construction out, but I'm not sure about how user-friendly that is.) The in-place replacement for perl is pretty simple, but Perl is becoming less common. For now, we'll just go with dos2unix.

check_ins: 2019-Jul-20 19:36   Check-in [57572]: (#7188) On the theory that it's almost never the right thing to do, don't even tell the user about -allow-crlf-script. (It's in the man page if they need it.) Instead, suggest running 'dos2unix'. (By Todd L Miller )
